title: 1 Peter Chapter 1 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Peter chapter 1 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Peter Chapter 1 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Peter Chapter 1.

questions.question: To whom is Peter writing in 1 Peter 1:1?
options: Strangers scattered throughout Pontus, Galatia, Cappadocia, Asia, and Bithynia
questions.correctAnswer: Strangers scattered throughout Pontus, Galatia, Cappadocia, Asia, and Bithynia
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:1 states that Peter is writing to strangers scattered throughout Pontus, Galatia, Cappadocia, Asia, and Bithynia.

questions.question: According to 1 Peter 1:3, what has God begotten us again unto?
options: A lively hope by the resurrection of Jesus Christ from the dead
questions.correctAnswer: A lively hope by the resurrection of Jesus Christ from the dead
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:3 describes God as having begotten us again unto a lively hope by the resurrection of Jesus Christ from the dead.

questions.question: What kind of inheritance is reserved in heaven for believers according to 1 Peter 1:4?
options: Incorruptible, undefiled, and that fadeth not away
questions.correctAnswer: Incorruptible, undefiled, and that fadeth not away
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:4 states the inheritance reserved in heaven is incorruptible, undefiled, and does not fade away.

questions.question: According to 1 Peter 1:5, who keeps believers through faith unto salvation?
questions.correctAnswer: The power of God
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:5 says believers are kept by the power of God through faith unto salvation.

questions.question: What does 1 Peter 1:6 say believers may experience for a season?
questions.correctAnswer: Heaviness through manifold temptations
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:6 states that believers may be in heaviness through manifold temptations for a season.

questions.question: According to 1 Peter 1:8, what kind of joy do believers have even though they have not seen Jesus?
options: Joy unspeakable and full of glory
questions.correctAnswer: Joy unspeakable and full of glory
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:8 describes the joy of believers as unspeakable and full of glory despite not having seen Jesus.

questions.question: Who diligently searched and prophesied about the grace that would come, according to 1 Peter 1:10?
questions.correctAnswer: The prophets
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:10 explains that the prophets diligently searched and prophesied about the grace that should come.

questions.question: What does 1 Peter 1:13 instruct believers to do with the loins of their mind?
options: Gird up the loins of your mind
questions.correctAnswer: Gird up the loins of your mind
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:13 instructs believers to gird up the loins of their mind, be sober, and hope to the end.

questions.question: According to 1 Peter 1:15, how should believers be holy?
questions.correctAnswer: In all manner of conversation
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:15 commands believers to be holy in all manner of conversation because God who called them is holy.

questions.question: What does 1 Peter 1:18 say believers were not redeemed with?
options: Corruptible things such as silver and gold
questions.correctAnswer: Corruptible things such as silver and gold
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:18 states that believers were not redeemed with corruptible things like silver and gold.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Peter 1:16 says, 'Be ye holy; for I am holy.'
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:16 quotes Scripture instructing believers to be holy as God is holy.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Peter 1:20, Christ was foreordained before the foundation of the world but made manifest in the last times for us.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:20 confirms Christ was foreordained before the foundation of the world and revealed in the last times.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Peter 1:25 states that the word of the Lord is temporary and fades like grass and flowers.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:25 says the word of the Lord endureth forever, unlike grass and flowers which wither and fall away.

questions.question: Complete the verse from 1 Peter 1:19: 'But with the precious blood of Christ, as of a lamb without ______ and without spot.'
questions.correctAnswer: blemish
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:19 describes Christ's blood as precious, as of a lamb without blemish and without spot.

questions.question: Complete the verse from 1 Peter 1:23: 'Being born again, not of corruptible seed, but of ______, by the word of God.'
questions.correctAnswer: incorruptible
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:23 teaches believers are born again of incorruptible seed by the word of God.

medium.title: 1 Peter Chapter 1 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Peter Chapter 1 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on 1 Peter 1, what biblical truth would you share about the purpose of trials?
options: Trials test faith and result in praise, honor, and glory at Christ's appearing
Trials are punishments for sin and should be avoided at all costs
Trials prove that God has abandoned believers
Trials are irrelevant to the Christian life
questions.correctAnswer: Trials test faith and result in praise, honor, and glory at Christ's appearing
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:6-7 teaches that trials test the genuineness of faith, which is more precious than gold, and they lead to praise, honor, and glory when Jesus Christ appears. This encourages perseverance and hope during difficulties.

questions.question: How does 1 Peter 1 instruct believers to live in holiness while they are 'sojourning' in this world?
options: By fearing God who judges impartially according to works
By focusing only on earthly success
questions.correctAnswer: By fearing God who judges impartially according to works
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:17 exhorts believers to live in reverent fear during their earthly sojourning because God judges impartially according to each person's deeds. This encourages holy living motivated by accountability to God.

questions.question: What does 1 Peter 1 say about the nature of the inheritance believers have in heaven?
options: It is incorruptible, undefiled, and unfading
It is temporary and subject to loss
questions.correctAnswer: It is incorruptible, undefiled, and unfading
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:4 describes the inheritance as imperishable, undefiled, and unfading, reserved in heaven for believers, emphasizing its eternal and secure nature.

questions.question: According to 1 Peter 1, what is the basis for believers' redemption?
options: The precious blood of Christ, like a lamb without blemish
questions.correctAnswer: The precious blood of Christ, like a lamb without blemish
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:18-19 explains that believers were redeemed not with corruptible things like silver or gold, but with the precious blood of Christ, who was without blemish and spot, highlighting the divine sacrifice for salvation.

questions.question: How does 1 Peter 1 encourage believers to relate to one another within the church community?
options: By loving one another earnestly with a pure heart
By competing for status and recognition
By avoiding fellowship to prevent conflict
By only associating with those who are perfect
questions.correctAnswer: By loving one another earnestly with a pure heart
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:22 calls believers to sincere love for one another, purified by obedience to the truth through the Spirit, stressing the importance of genuine brotherly love in Christian fellowship.

questions.question: What does 1 Peter 1 teach about the believer's hope and joy, even without seeing Jesus physically?
options: Believers rejoice with joy unspeakable and full of glory through faith
Believers must see Jesus to have true joy
Joy is based solely on circumstances
Hope is irrelevant without physical proof
questions.correctAnswer: Believers rejoice with joy unspeakable and full of glory through faith
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:8 emphasizes that believers love and rejoice in Jesus, whom they have not seen, by faith, resulting in joy that is inexpressible and glorious.

questions.question: According to 1 Peter 1, how should believers prepare their minds for the future grace to be revealed at Jesus Christ's coming?
options: By being sober, self-controlled, and hopeful
By relying on their own strength only
questions.correctAnswer: By being sober, self-controlled, and hopeful
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:13 instructs believers to prepare their minds, be sober and set their hope fully on the grace that will be given at the revelation of Jesus Christ, encouraging spiritual readiness and hope.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Peter 1, believers are called to be holy because God who called them is holy.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:15-16 commands believers to be holy in all their conduct because God, who called them, is holy, establishing the basis for Christian holiness.

questions.question: True or False: The prophets in the Old Testament prophesied for their own benefit and understanding, not for future believers.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:10-12 reveals that the prophets searched and inquired about the salvation and grace coming to believers, and the things they prophesied were for future recipients of the Gospel, not for themselves alone.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'Being born again, not of corruptible seed, but of ________, by the word of God, which liveth and abideth for ever.'
questions.correctAnswer: incorruptible
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:23 states that believers are born again through the incorruptible seed, which is the word of God, emphasizing the eternal and life-giving nature of God's word.

questions.question: How does 1 Peter 1 describe the Christian's conduct in relation to former lusts and ignorance?
options: Believers should not conform to their former lusts but live as obedient children
Believers should indulge their former lusts to overcome them
Ignorance is acceptable in the Christian life
Former lusts define a believer's identity
questions.correctAnswer: Believers should not conform to their former lusts but live as obedient children
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:14 urges believers to live as obedient children and not to fashion themselves according to the former lusts they had in ignorance, promoting a transformed lifestyle.

questions.question: According to 1 Peter 1, what is the role of the Holy Spirit in the believer's sanctification?
options: The Spirit sanctifies believers leading to obedience and sprinkling of Jesus’ blood
The Spirit is irrelevant to Christian obedience
The Spirit causes believers to be isolated
questions.correctAnswer: The Spirit sanctifies believers leading to obedience and sprinkling of Jesus’ blood
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:2 highlights that believers are elect through the foreknowledge of God, sanctified by the Spirit, unto obedience and the sprinkling of the blood of Jesus Christ, showing the Spirit’s vital role in sanctification and obedience.

questions.question: What does 1 Peter 1 say about the permanence of human life compared to God's word?
options: Human life is like grass that withers, but God's word endures forever
Human life is eternal and God's word changes frequently
questions.correctAnswer: Human life is like grass that withers, but God's word endures forever
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:24-25 teaches that all flesh is like grass and the glory of man like a flower that fades, but the word of the Lord endures forever, emphasizing the eternal nature of God's word over human mortality.

questions.question: Based on 1 Peter 1, how should believers view their faith and hope?
options: They should place their faith and hope in God who raised Jesus from the dead
They should rely on their own strength for hope
Hope should be placed only in earthly things
questions.correctAnswer: They should place their faith and hope in God who raised Jesus from the dead
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:21 teaches that by Jesus, believers believe in God who raised Him from the dead and gave Him glory, so that their faith and hope are set on God, emphasizing the divine foundation of Christian hope.

questions.question: How does 1 Peter 1 describe the calling of believers in relation to God's holiness?
options: Believers are called to be holy in all their conduct because God is holy
Believers have no obligation to imitate God's holiness
God's holiness is separate from believers' lives
questions.correctAnswer: Believers are called to be holy in all their conduct because God is holy
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:15-16 commands believers to be holy in all manner of conduct since God who calls them is holy, highlighting holiness as a fundamental Christian virtue.

hard.title: 1 Peter Chapter 1 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Peter Chapter 1.

questions.question: To whom is Peter addressing his letter in 1 Peter 1:1?
options: Strangers scattered throughout Pontus, Galatia, Cappadocia, Asia, and Bithynia
questions.correctAnswer: Strangers scattered throughout Pontus, Galatia, Cappadocia, Asia, and Bithynia
questions.explanation: Peter explicitly addresses 'strangers scattered throughout Pontus, Galatia, Cappadocia, Asia, and Bithynia' in 1 Peter 1:1, indicating his audience were dispersed believers in these regions.

questions.question: What is the significance of being 'elect according to the foreknowledge of God' in 1 Peter 1:2?
options: It highlights God's sovereign choice in salvation
It implies human merit in election
It refers to political election in Roman society
It means believers must earn sanctification
questions.correctAnswer: It highlights God's sovereign choice in salvation
questions.explanation: The phrase 'elect according to the foreknowledge of God' (1 Peter 1:2) underscores God's sovereign predestination and foreknowledge in choosing believers, a theme consistent with Pauline theology.

questions.question: How does the 'lively hope' mentioned in 1 Peter 1:3 relate to Old Testament resurrection themes?
options: It echoes the hope of resurrection seen in Isaiah and Daniel
It contradicts Old Testament views of death
It only refers to earthly prosperity
It is unrelated to any Old Testament concept
questions.correctAnswer: It echoes the hope of resurrection seen in Isaiah and Daniel
questions.explanation: The 'lively hope' through Christ’s resurrection (1 Peter 1:3) connects to Old Testament prophecies about resurrection and restoration, such as in Isaiah 26:19 and Daniel 12:2, demonstrating continuity in biblical eschatology.

questions.question: What literary device is primarily used in 1 Peter 1:4 describing the inheritance as 'incorruptible, undefiled, and fadeth not away'?
questions.correctAnswer: Triadic parallelism to emphasize permanency
questions.explanation: The threefold description 'incorruptible, undefiled, and fadeth not away' (1 Peter 1:4) uses triadic parallelism, a Hebrew poetic device emphasizing the eternal and unchanging nature of the heavenly inheritance.

questions.question: According to 1 Peter 1:5, by what means are believers kept until salvation is revealed?
options: By the power of God through faith
Through adherence to the Mosaic Law
questions.correctAnswer: By the power of God through faith
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:5 states believers are 'kept by the power of God through faith,' emphasizing divine preservation rather than human effort, reflecting the theme of God’s sustaining grace.

questions.question: In 1 Peter 1:7, the trial of faith is compared to what, and what is its intended effect?
options: More precious than gold, testing produces praise, honor, and glory
Less valuable than silver, leading to despair
Like a fleeting shadow, resulting in doubt
questions.correctAnswer: More precious than gold, testing produces praise, honor, and glory
questions.explanation: The trial of faith is 'more precious than gold' (1 Peter 1:7), and though tested by fire, it results in praise, honor, and glory when Jesus Christ appears, illustrating the refining nature of suffering.

questions.question: What is the paradox presented in 1 Peter 1:8 regarding the believers’ relationship with Jesus?
options: They love Him without seeing Him, yet rejoice with unspeakable joy
They see Jesus physically but lack faith
They doubt His resurrection despite evidence
They love Jesus only because of His miracles
questions.correctAnswer: They love Him without seeing Him, yet rejoice with unspeakable joy
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:8 presents the paradox that believers love Jesus 'whom having not seen,' and 'though now ye see him not, yet believing,' they rejoice with 'joy unspeakable and full of glory,' highlighting faith’s triumph over sight.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Peter 1:10-12, the Old Testament prophets fully understood the timing and nature of the salvation now revealed in the New Testament.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:10-12 explains that prophets searched and inquired about the salvation and sufferings of Christ, but it was revealed that they ministered not to themselves but to the future believers, indicating partial understanding.

questions.question: What cultural metaphor does Peter use in 1 Peter 1:13 when urging believers to 'gird up the loins of your mind'?
options: Preparing for action like tightening a robe for running
Building a physical fence around the mind
Putting on armor like a Roman soldier
Lighting a lamp to illuminate understanding
questions.correctAnswer: Preparing for action like tightening a robe for running
questions.explanation: The phrase 'gird up the loins' (1 Peter 1:13) alludes to the ancient practice of tucking long robes into a belt to prepare for swift movement, symbolizing mental readiness and sobriety for Christian living.

questions.question: How does 1 Peter 1:15-16 use Old Testament allusion to emphasize holiness?
options: By quoting Leviticus 11:44, 'Be ye holy; for I am holy'
By referencing the Ten Commandments verbatim
By citing Psalms about the Messiah
By recalling the covenant with Abraham
questions.correctAnswer: By quoting Leviticus 11:44, 'Be ye holy; for I am holy'
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:16 directly quotes Leviticus 11:44 to command holiness, connecting the New Testament call for holy conduct with Israel’s covenantal standards.

questions.question: According to 1 Peter 1:17, what attitude should believers maintain during their 'sojourning' in this world?
options: Fear of God who judges impartially
questions.correctAnswer: Fear of God who judges impartially
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:17 instructs believers to live in reverent fear of God, who judges impartially based on each person’s works, emphasizing accountability during their earthly pilgrimage.

questions.question: What contrast does Peter make in 1 Peter 1:18-19 regarding the nature of redemption?
options: Redeemed not with corruptible silver or gold, but with precious blood of Christ
Redeemed by human effort rather than divine grace
Redeemed with earthly wealth and possessions
questions.correctAnswer: Redeemed not with corruptible silver or gold, but with precious blood of Christ
questions.explanation: Peter contrasts earthly corruptible things like silver and gold with the 'precious blood of Christ' (1 Peter 1:18-19), emphasizing the superior and divine nature of redemption.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Christ was foreordained before the foundation of the world but was __________ in these last times for you (1 Peter 1:20).
questions.correctAnswer: manifest
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:20 states Christ was 'foreordained before the foundation of the world' but was 'manifest in these last times,' highlighting the incarnation and revelation of Christ in history.

questions.question: How does 1 Peter 1:22 describe the relationship between obeying the truth and loving the brethren?
options: Obedience to truth purifies the soul leading to fervent and pure love
Love replaces the need for obedience
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to truth purifies the soul leading to fervent and pure love
questions.explanation: According to 1 Peter 1:22, obeying the truth through the Spirit purifies the soul, which results in a fervent and pure love for the brethren, linking holiness with communal love.

questions.question: What typology is evident in 1 Peter 1:19 describing Christ as 'a lamb without blemish and without spot'?
options: Christ as the fulfillment of the Passover lamb
Christ as the Ark of the Covenant
Christ as the serpent lifted in the wilderness
questions.correctAnswer: Christ as the fulfillment of the Passover lamb
questions.explanation: Describing Christ as 'a lamb without blemish' (1 Peter 1:19) draws on the Passover lamb typology from Exodus 12, signifying Christ's sacrificial role for redemption.

theological.title: 1 Peter Chapter 1 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Peter Chapter 1 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to 1 Peter 1:3, what is the source of the 'lively hope' believers have?
options: The resurrection of Jesus Christ from the dead
questions.correctAnswer: The resurrection of Jesus Christ from the dead
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:3 states that believers are begotten again unto a lively hope by the resurrection of Jesus Christ from the dead. This hope is grounded in Christ's victory over death, consistent with Romans 6:4 and Acts 2:24 which affirm resurrection as the foundation of Christian hope.

questions.question: What kind of inheritance is reserved for believers according to 1 Peter 1:4?
questions.correctAnswer: Incorruptible, undefiled, and unfading
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:4 describes the inheritance as incorruptible, undefiled, and unfading, reserved in heaven. This corresponds with Jesus' teaching in Matthew 6:20 on heavenly treasures, and Paul's words in 1 Corinthians 9:25 about an incorruptible crown.

questions.question: According to 1 Peter 1:5, by what power are believers kept until salvation is revealed?
options: The power of God through faith
questions.correctAnswer: The power of God through faith
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:5 states believers are kept by the power of God through faith, highlighting divine preservation rather than human effort. This aligns with Jude 1:24 and Philippians 1:6 which affirm God's sustaining power for believers.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the trials of faith mentioned in 1 Peter 1:7?
options: To result in praise, honor, and glory at the appearing of Jesus Christ
To separate the righteous from the unrighteous
questions.correctAnswer: To result in praise, honor, and glory at the appearing of Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:7 teaches that trials refine faith like gold tested by fire, resulting in praise, honor, and glory when Christ appears. This is consistent with James 1:2-4 and Romans 5:3-5 about the refining and strengthening purpose of trials.

questions.question: How does 1 Peter 1:8 describe the believers' relationship to Christ whom they have not seen?
options: They love Him and rejoice with joy unspeakable and full of glory
They rely on visible signs only
They fear Him as a harsh judge
questions.correctAnswer: They love Him and rejoice with joy unspeakable and full of glory
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:8 describes believers loving Christ without seeing Him and rejoicing with unspeakable joy. This faith and love are foundational, as also emphasized in John 20:29 and Romans 8:24-25 regarding belief without seeing.

questions.question: What did the prophets do concerning the salvation now revealed to believers, according to 1 Peter 1:10?
options: They inquired and searched diligently about it
They only spoke about earthly kings
They predicted the destruction of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: They inquired and searched diligently about it
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:10 highlights that prophets searched and inquired diligently about the salvation now revealed, indicating Old Testament anticipation of the Messiah (cf. Isaiah 53; Daniel 9:24-27; Luke 24:25-27).

questions.question: Who sent the Holy Spirit that accompanied the gospel preached to believers, as mentioned in 1 Peter 1:12?
questions.correctAnswer: Heaven
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:12 states the gospel was preached with the Holy Ghost sent down from heaven, affirming the divine origin of the Spirit's work, consistent with Acts 2:33 and John 15:26.

questions.question: What attitude does 1 Peter 1:13 command believers to have in their minds?
options: Gird up the loins of your mind, be sober, and hope to the end
Follow the lusts of former ignorance
questions.correctAnswer: Gird up the loins of your mind, be sober, and hope to the end
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:13 calls for mental readiness, sobriety, and enduring hope. This exhortation corresponds with Paul's teaching in Ephesians 6:14 and 1 Thessalonians 5:6 about alertness and hope.

questions.question: According to 1 Peter 1:15-16, why are believers called to be holy in their conduct?
options: Because God who called them is holy
questions.correctAnswer: Because God who called them is holy
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:15-16 instructs holiness because the one who calls believers is holy, referencing Leviticus 11:44-45 where God commands holiness. This divine attribute sets the standard for believer conduct.

questions.question: What does 1 Peter 1:17 say about the nature of God as Judge?
options: He judges impartially according to each one's work
questions.correctAnswer: He judges impartially according to each one's work
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:17 affirms God as an impartial judge who judges according to every man's work, echoing Deuteronomy 10:17 and Romans 2:11 on God's impartiality and justice.

questions.question: According to 1 Peter 1:18-19, by what means were believers redeemed?
options: By the precious blood of Christ, a lamb without blemish and without spot
questions.correctAnswer: By the precious blood of Christ, a lamb without blemish and without spot
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:18-19 contrasts redemption by corruptible things with redemption through the precious blood of Christ, symbolizing the spotless Lamb, consistent with Exodus 12:5 and John 1:29.

questions.question: What is said about Christ's foreordination in 1 Peter 1:20?
options: He was foreordained before the foundation of the world
He was a mere human like others
He was a prophet raised up in the last days
questions.correctAnswer: He was foreordained before the foundation of the world
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:20 declares Christ was foreordained before the foundation of the world, affirming his eternal divine purpose, aligning with John 1:1-2 and Revelation 13:8.

questions.question: What does 1 Peter 1:21 say is the purpose of believing in God through Christ?
options: That your faith and hope might be in God
That you might earn salvation by works
That you might gain earthly power
questions.correctAnswer: That your faith and hope might be in God
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:21 explains believers trust in the God who raised Jesus, so their faith and hope rest in God. This is consistent with Hebrews 11:1 and Romans 15:13 emphasizing faith and hope in God alone.

questions.question: According to 1 Peter 1:22, what results from obeying the truth through the Spirit?
options: Purified souls and unfeigned love of the brethren
questions.correctAnswer: Purified souls and unfeigned love of the brethren
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:22 teaches that obedience through the Spirit purifies souls and produces sincere brotherly love, consistent with John 13:34-35 and Galatians 5:22-23 on the fruit of the Spirit.

questions.question: What type of seed are believers born again from, according to 1 Peter 1:23?
options: Incorruptible seed by the word of God
questions.correctAnswer: Incorruptible seed by the word of God
questions.explanation: 1 Peter 1:23 states believers are born again not of corruptible seed but incorruptible, by the eternal word of God. This metaphor aligns with Jesus' teaching in John 3:3-8 and Isaiah 40:8 about the enduring word.
